urls.title: Water firms are main source of microplastics in UK rivers, study says
urls.description: Research says discharge of untreated sewage and wastewater during dry spells to blame

tweets.text:
Important new research out today by @Jamie_Woodward_ & others identifies water firms as the main source of microplastics in UK rivers. 

Builds more pressure on government @EnvAgency to tackle the way water firms release untreated effluent into our rivers.
https://t.co/HKK1Ar0abP

Astonishing revelations in this week's update:

* the EA were not "consulted", as Red claimed, merely informed
* four waste loads rejected
* the EA are "now actively auditing the supply chain of waste to the site"
* Odour above annoyance levels *48%* of the time on Galingale View https://t.co/7p4IBAt2dt

#Mentalhealth is just as important as physical health. 

It‚Äôs OK to talk about your mental health and it‚Äôs OK not to be OK. 

If you‚Äôre suffering and you don‚Äôt know who to talk to @samaritans helpline is open around the clock on 116 123. 

Make sure you get the support you need. https://t.co/uSIAMp2Tl9

@davemh72 @SOPH_C_ @EnvAgency @StinkStopthe 100% in agreement with you. In fact I can't trust anyone of these involved in this matter.

The Environment Agency says the operators of Walleys Quarry will no longer accept waste from one of the companies who was trying to dispose of waste at the site. 

It says it will be investigating the waste operators whose rubbish was refused.

The update says four separate waste loads were rejected because it wasn‚Äôt what Walleys Quarry is allowed to accept. 

The Environment Agency says it is ‚Äòactively auditing‚Äô the supply chain of waste to the site.
